events.title: Enemy Forces Launch Coordinated Assault on Cos as Royal Navy Struggles to Intercept Reinforcements
events.description: 201. From air reconnaissance carried out on Ist and 2nd October, it was known that a considerable enemy convoy was at sea; on the and it was sailing east in Naxos area, and the garrison commander on Cos assumed it was a reinforcement for Rhodes. The enemy's air superiority made it impossible for the Royal Navy to intercept the convoy by day, and a sweep carried out by destroyers on the night of 2nd October failed to locate it, At first light on the following day R.A.F. Beaufighters attacked the convoy, but without success. The garrison was therefore only conducting its ordinary routine precautions when, at 0500 hours on 3rd October, the enemy assault on Cos began, The seaborne invading forces, consisting of troops from the Greek mainland and from Crete, landed from merchant vessels, landing-craft and caiques, covered by aircraft and three destroyers, while a strong force of parachute troops, flown from the Greek mainland, was dropped on Antimachia airfield, which our aircraft were unable to use since it had been badly cratered in the air-raids which

events.title: Germans Assert Air Dominance in Aegean, Capture Leros as Allies Evacuate Samos
events.description: to. With Rhodes, Crete and the airfields on the Greek mainland at their disposal, the Germans had command of the air in the Aigean, and with the less of our only ianding grounds at Cos on 2nd October we were unable to ship adequate reinforcements and were in no position to defend the other two islands. Leros was captured by assault, after a prolonged bombing and dive-bombing attack, on 16th November, and Samos was evacuated in the next few days.

events.title: Middle East Command Oversaw Logistics as 43,500 Tons of Supplies Delivered in Critical Operation
events.description: 166. Middle East Command was responsible for maintaining this force for the first three weeks of the operation, that is to say, from gth September to 2nd October. For this period, convoys were loaded with 43,500 tons of stores.

events.title: Allied Forces Streamline Operations: New Eastern and Western Group System Implemented in Italy
events.description: 167. From 2nd October onwards, maintenance of the force in Italy was on the basis of the Eastern and Western Group system, which was also being used for the other forces, including Eighth Army, in Sicily and Italy. Under this system the War Office made demands on Middle East, fbut in order to simplify the shipping problem Allied Force Headquarters also informed Middle East, every ten days, of the separate demands for Naples and the toe of Italy respectively.

events.title: Weather Woes and Enemy Tactics Strain Reinforcements to Leros Garrison
events.description: bases and shipping was limited by the weather and the temporary unserviceability of our Cyrenaican landing grounds owing to rain. The enemy, on the other hand, taking full advantage of the proximity of his air bases, was able to make our reinforcements of Leros difficult. The dropping of flares at night hindered unloading operations on certain occasions, and the laying of minefields also added to our difficulties; in spite of all this enemy activity the strength of the Leros garrison was built up to the strength of a brigade. The original garrison, which had arrived between the 17th September and the 2nd October, was the 234th Brigade Headquarters, and the 2nd Royal Irish Fusiliers, with a company from the 2nd Royal West Kents, the remainder of the battalion being on Samos. This was reinforced by 4th November by the 4th Buffs, although their Headquarters Company was lost at sea, and early in November the Ist King's Own completed the Brigade.

events.title: Minimal Resistance Encountered as Occupation of Fianarantsoa Commences After Road-Block Struggles
events.description: GAZETTE, 17 JULY, 1946 3719 occupied on 2nd October and Fianarantsoa on the 2gth. A few engagefnents took place but again opposition was mainly from road-blocks and demolitions.
